ground_truth: At first only the turrets and rooftops are visible against a torrid sky. The facades of the Moorish buildings give way to a narrow, twisting street crowded with the polyglot life of a native quarter. The narrator's voice fades away. A police officer takes a piece of paper from the typewriter, turns to a microphone, and reads. An officer blows his whistle several times. There is pandemonium as native guards begin to round up people. A police car, full of officers, with siren blaring, screams through the street and stops in the market. Some try to escape but are caught by the police and loaded into a police wagon. At a street corner, two policemen stop a white civilian and question him. The civilian pats his pockets and brings out his papers. The second policeman examines them. Suddenly the civilian breaks away and starts to run wildly down the street. Jan and Annina Brandel, a very young and attractive refugee couple from Bulgaria, watch as the civilian passes. They've been thrust by circumstances from a simple country life into an unfamiliar and hectic world. A shot rings out, and the man falls to the ground. The policeman frantically searches the body, but only finds Free French literature. A European man, sitting at a table nearby, watches the English couple more closely than the scene on the street. A middle-aged English couple sit at a table just off the square and observe the commotion across the way in front of the Palais de Justice. The European walks over to the couple. The police van pulls up. The rear doors are opened and people stream out. Suspects are herded out of the van and into the Palais de Justice. At the entrance, the arrested suspects are led in by the police. He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishman and reaches behind the man with his right hand. The Englishman seems to be taken aback by this sudden display of concern. As he pats both his breast and pants pockets he realizes there is something missing. The plane swoops down past a sign atop a building at the edge of the airport. As the plane lands a swastika on its tail is clearly visible. It taxis to a stop as a group of officers march into formation in front of it. Behind them stand a detail of native soldiers keeping guard. In the group is Captain Louis Renault, a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca. When the plane door opens, the first passenger to step out is a tall, middle-aged, pale German with a smile that seems more the result of a frozen face muscle than a cheerful disposition.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: At first only the towers and rooftops are perceptible against a scorching sky. The facades of the Moorish edifices give way to a narrow, meandering avenue crowded with the multilingual life of a native district. The storyteller's voice diminishes. A law officer takes a sheet of paper from the typewriter, turns to a microphone, and reads. An officer blows his whistle several times. There is chaos as native guards begin to round up individuals. A patrol car, full of officers, with siren blaring, screams through the street and halts in the marketplace. Some attempt to flee but are apprehended by the police and loaded into a police wagon. At a street corner, two officers stop a Caucasian civilian and interrogate him. The civilian pats his pockets and brings out his documents. The second officer inspects them. Suddenly the civilian breaks away and starts to run wildly down the avenue. Jan and Annina Brandel, a very young and appealing refugee pair from Bulgaria, watch as the civilian passes. They've been propelled by circumstances from a simple rural life into an unfamiliar and frantic world. A gunshot rings out, and the man collapses to the ground. The officer frantically searches the body, but only discovers Free French literature. A European man, sitting at a table nearby, observes the English pair more intently than the spectacle on the street. A middle-aged English pair sit at a table just off the square and observe the hubbub across the way in front of the Palais de Justice. The European strides over to the pair. The police van pulls up. The rear doors are opened, and individuals stream out. Suspects are herded out of the van and into the Palais de Justice. At the entrance, the apprehended suspects are led in by the police. He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishman and reaches behind the man with his right hand. The Englishman seems to be startled by this sudden display of concern. As he pats both his chest and trousers pockets he realizes there is something absent. The aircraft swoops down past a sign atop a structure at the edge of the airport. As the aircraft lands a swastika on its tail is clearly visible. It taxis to a halt as a group of officers march into formation in front of it. Behind them stand a detachment of native soldiers keeping watch. In the group is Captain Louis Renault, a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca. When the aircraft door opens, the first traveler to step out is a tall, middle-aged, pale German with a grin that seems more the result of a frozen face muscle than a cheerful disposition.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: At first, only the turrets and rooftops are seen against a torrid sky. A narrow, twisting street crowded with the polyglot life of a native quarter is revealed by the facades of the Moorish buildings. The narrator's voice is faded away by time. A piece of paper is taken from the typewriter by a police officer, who then turns to a microphone and reads. Several whistles are blown by an officer. Pandemonium ensues as people are rounded up by native guards. The street is screamed through by a police car, full of officers, with siren blaring, and it is stopped in the market. Some try to escape but the police catch them and load them into a police wagon. At a street corner, a white civilian is stopped and questioned by two policemen. His pockets are patted by the civilian, who brings out his papers. The papers are examined by the second policeman. Suddenly, the civilian breaks away and wildly runs down the street. Jan and Annina Brandel, a very young and attractive refugee couple from Bulgaria, watch as the civilian passes. Circumstances have thrust them from a simple country life into an unfamiliar and hectic world. A shot is fired, and the man is brought down to the ground. The body is searched frantically by the policeman, but he only finds Free French literature. The English couple is watched more closely than the scene on the street by a European man sitting at a table nearby. A middle-aged English couple sits at a table just off the square and observes the commotion across the way in front of the Palais de Justice. The couple is approached by the European. The police van pulls up. The rear doors are opened and people are streamed out. Suspects are herded out of the van and into the Palais de Justice. At the entrance, the police lead in the arrested suspects. His left arm is put compassionately around the Englishman and the man is reached behind with his right hand by him. The Englishman is taken aback by this sudden display of concern. As both his breast and pants pockets are patted by him, he realizes there is something missing. A plane swoops down past a sign atop a building at the edge of the airport. A swastika on its tail is clearly visible as the plane lands. It is taxied to a stop as a group of officers march into formation in front of it. Behind them, a detail of native soldiers keeps guard. Captain Louis Renault, a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca, is in the group. When the plane door opens, a tall, middle-aged, pale German, with a smile that seems more the result of a frozen face muscle than a cheerful disposition, steps out first.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Initially, only the rooftops and turrets are visible against a stormy sky. Moorish building facades lead to a narrow, winding street bustling with diverse life. The narrator's voice fades. A police officer takes a paper from a typewriter, turns to a microphone, and reads. Another officer repeatedly blows his whistle, causing chaos as native guards round up people. A police car, siren wailing, speeds through the street and stops at the market. Some attempt escape but are caught and loaded into a wagon. At a corner, two policemen stop a white civilian, who retrieves his papers. The second officer examines them, but suddenly the civilian flees. Jan and Annina Brandel, young refugees from Bulgaria, watch him pass. A shot is fired, and the man falls. The policeman finds only Free French literature on him. A nearby European man watches an English couple more closely than the street scene. The European approaches them as the police van arrives. Suspects are led into the Palais de Justice. The European puts his arm around the Englishman, who realizes something is missing. A plane lands, its tail showing a swastika, stopping in front of officers. Among them is Captain Louis Renault, Vichy-appointed Prefect of Police in Casablanca. A tall, middle-aged German with a fixed smile exits the plane first.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Initially, only turrets and rooftops appear against a torrid sky. Moorish facades open to a twisting street bustling with a diverse native crowd. The narrator's voice fades. A police officer removes a paper from a typewriter, turns to a microphone, and reads. Pandemonium ensues as native guards round up people. A siren-blaring police car, full of officers, speeds through the street and halts at the market. Escapees are caught, loaded into a police van. Two policemen stop a white civilian, who retrieves papers from his pockets. The second officer examines them, but the civilian suddenly flees. Jan and Annina Brandel, a young attractive Bulgarian refugee couple, watch him pass by. They're thrust from a simple country life into chaos. A shot rings; the man falls. Policemen find only Free French literature on him. Nearby, a European man observes the English couple more intently than the street scene. A middle-aged English couple sits near the square, watching the commotion by the Palais de Justice. The European approaches them. The police van arrives; suspects exit and are led into the Palais de Justice. The European compassionately drapes his arm around the Englishman, who pats his pockets and notices something missing. A plane descends past an airport sign, with a visible swastika on its tail. It stops as officers march in formation before it, with native soldiers standing guard. Among them is Captain Louis Renault, a French Vichy-appointed Police Prefect in Casablanca. A tall, middle-aged, pale German, smiling stiffly, is the first passenger to disembark.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Initially, only the decorative turrets and rooftops are distinguishable against the backdrop of a torrid, blazing sky. Gradually, the facades of the elegant Moorish buildings give way to reveal a narrow, twisting street that is bustling with the vibrant, diverse life characteristic of a native quarter. The narrator's voice begins to fade away softly. A police officer, standing with authority, extracts a piece of paper from a typewriter, turns to a nearby microphone, and proceeds to read aloud. Another officer, standing vigilantly, blows his whistle multiple times, signaling a call to action. Chaos ensues as native guards commence rounding up the crowd of people. A police car, brimming with officers and with its siren blaring noisily, screams through the narrow street before coming to a dramatic halt in the busy market. Some individuals attempt to flee the scene but are quickly apprehended by the police and subsequently loaded into a waiting police wagon. At a street corner, two policemen intercept a white civilian and proceed to question him. The civilian, looking somewhat nervous, pats his pockets before producing his identification papers. The second policeman scrutinizes the papers carefully. In an unexpected turn of events, the civilian suddenly breaks away from the officers and begins to run wildly down the street. Observing the scene are Jan and Annina Brandel, an exceptionally young and attractive refugee couple hailing from Bulgaria. They have been unexpectedly thrust by circumstances from their simple country life into an unfamiliar and hectic world. A shot rings out abruptly, and the man collapses to the ground. The policeman rushes to search the body frantically, only to find Free French literature. Nearby, a European man seated at a table watches the English couple with more interest than the escalating scene on the street. Meanwhile, a middle-aged English couple is seated at a table just off the square, observing the commotion unfolding across the way in front of the imposing Palais de Justice. The European man stands and walks over to engage with the couple. The police van pulls up with urgency. As the rear doors are opened, people are ushered out in a hurried stream. The suspects are herded out of the van and guided into the Palais de Justice, led in by the police stationed at the entrance. The European man then places his left arm around the Englishman in a gesture of compassion and reaches behind him with his right hand. The Englishman appears taken aback by this sudden display of concern and, as he pats both his breast and pants pockets, realizes there is something now missing. A plane swoops down past a sign perched atop a building at the edge of the bustling airport. As the plane makes its landing, a swastika emblazoned on its tail becomes clearly visible. It taxis to a halt as a group of uniformed officers march into an ordered formation in front of it. Behind them stands a detail of native soldiers vigilant and on guard. Within the group is Captain Louis Renault, a French officer who has been appointed by Vichy as the Prefect of Police in the city of Casablanca. When the door of the plane opens, the first passenger to emerge is a tall, middle-aged, pale German who wears a smile that seems more like the result of a frozen facial muscle than a manifestation of a cheerful disposition.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: At the very beginning, only the ornate decorative turrets and rooftops stand out distinctly against the backdrop of a torrid and intensely blazing sky. Bit by bit, the facades of the elegant and intricately designed Moorish buildings gradually become more visible, eventually giving way to unveil a narrow and twisting street that is teeming with the vibrant and diverse life that is so characteristic of a native quarter. As this unfolds, the narrator's voice begins to fade away softly, almost disappearing into the atmosphere. A police officer, standing with an air of authority, extracts a sheet of paper from a typewriter, turns towards a nearby microphone, and proceeds to read aloud. In the meantime, another officer, standing vigilantly and alert, blows his whistle multiple times, signaling a call to immediate action. Pandemonium ensues as native guards start rounding up the bustling crowd of people in a systematic manner. A police car, absolutely brimming with officers and with its siren blaring loudly and insistently, screams through the narrow street before coming to a dramatic and abrupt halt in the midst of the busy market. While some individuals make attempts to flee the chaotic scene, they are swiftly apprehended by the police and subsequently loaded into a waiting police wagon. At a street corner, two policemen intercept a white civilian and proceed to interrogate him. The civilian, looking somewhat nervous, pats his pockets before finally producing his identification papers. The second policeman scrutinizes these papers with a careful eye. In an unexpected and sudden turn of events, the civilian abruptly breaks away from the officers and begins to run wildly down the street. Observing this entire scene are Jan and Annina Brandel, an exceptionally young and attractive refugee couple hailing originally from Bulgaria. They have been unexpectedly thrust by circumstances from their simple, pastoral country life into an unfamiliar and hectic world. Suddenly, a shot rings out abruptly, and the man collapses to the ground. The policeman rushes over to search the body frantically, only to find Free French literature. Nearby, a European man seated casually at a table watches the English couple with more interest than the escalating scene taking place on the street. Meanwhile, a middle-aged English couple is also seated at a table just off the square, observing the commotion unfolding right across the way in front of the imposing and grand Palais de Justice. The European man stands up and walks over to engage in conversation with the couple. The police van then pulls up with a great sense of urgency. As the rear doors swing open, people are ushered out in a hurried and frantic stream. The suspects are herded out of the van and guided into the Palais de Justice, led in by the police officers stationed at the entrance. The European man then places his left arm around the Englishman in a gesture meant to convey compassion and reaches behind him with his right hand. The Englishman appears taken aback by this sudden and unexpected display of concern and, as he pats both his breast and pants pockets, he realizes there is something now missing. A plane swoops down past a sign perched atop a building at the very edge of the bustling airport. As the plane makes its descent and landing, a swastika emblazoned on its tail becomes clearly visible. It taxis to a halt as a group of uniformed officers march into an ordered and precise formation in front of it. Standing behind them is a detail of native soldiers who remain vigilant and on guard. Within this group is Captain Louis Renault, a French officer who has been appointed by Vichy as the Prefect of Police in the city of Casablanca. When the door of the plane opens, the first passenger to emerge is a tall, middle-aged, and rather pale German who wears a smile that seems more like the result of a frozen facial muscle than a true manifestation of a cheerful disposition.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Initially, the only things visible against a torrid sky are the turrets and rooftops, barely discernible as they silhouette against the bright backdrop. As the eye adjusts, the facades of Moorish buildings emerge, presenting a scene that gradually transitions into a narrow, twisting street. This street is teeming with the vibrant, diverse life characteristic of a native quarter, where varied cultural influences blend into a chaotic symphony. As the visuals take center stage, the narrator's voice gently fades away, leaving the scene to unfold in silence. A police officer, stationed somewhere amidst this bustling environment, completes a document on a typewriter, then smoothly pulls the freshly typed paper from the machine. He turns with purpose to a nearby microphone and begins to read aloud. Meanwhile, another officer, standing in a separate part of the area, brings a whistle to his lips and emits several sharp, piercing blows. The sound cuts through the air, triggering pandemonium as native guards swiftly spring into action, moving to round up people with an urgency that borders on chaos. A police car, packed with officers, hurtles through the crowded street, its siren wailing loudly. The car navigates through the throngs of people, finally coming to a jarring halt in the bustling market. As the scene erupts into further disorder, some individuals, driven by fear or desperation, attempt to flee. However, their efforts prove futile as the police swiftly apprehend them, ushering them into the back of a police wagon. Nearby, on a street corner, two policemen intercept a white civilian. They engage him in questioning, prompting the civilian to pat his pockets in search of his identification. He produces his papers, which the second policeman scrutinizes closely. In an unexpected turn of events, the civilian abruptly breaks free from the interaction, launching into a wild, frantic sprint down the street. Among the onlookers, Jan and Annina Brandel, a young and striking refugee couple from Bulgaria, stand as reluctant witnesses to the unfolding drama. Their presence in this unfamiliar and frenetic world is a stark contrast to their simple country life back home. Suddenly, a gunshot pierces the air, and the fleeing man collapses to the ground. A policeman rushes to the fallen figure, urgently searching the body, but his efforts uncover only Free French literature. Nearby, a European man sits at a table, visibly more interested in observing the English couple near him than the chaos playing out on the street. This middle-aged English couple is seated just off the square, their focus directed towards the commotion occurring in front of the Palais de Justice. The European man rises from his seat and approaches them. Meanwhile, the police van draws near and comes to a stop. The rear doors of the van swing open, and people begin to stream out, suspects being herded by the officers as they make their way into the Palais de Justice. At the entrance, the arrested individuals are guided inside by the police in a somber procession. The European man then makes a surprising gesture, placing his left arm gently and supportively around the Englishman. As he does so, his right hand discreetly reaches behind the Englishman. Startled by this unexpected show of compassion, the Englishman instinctively pats his breast and pants pockets, only to discover that something important is missing. Attention shifts to the airport, where a plane descends from the sky, gliding down past a sign that crowns a building positioned at the edge of the airport. As the plane lands, the swastika emblazoned on its tail becomes prominently visible. The plane taxis to a halt, and a group of officers assembles into a formation before it, their precise movements reflecting discipline and authority. Positioned behind this group, a detail of native soldiers stands vigilantly, maintaining their guard. Among the officers is Captain Louis Renault, a French officer who holds the position of Prefect of Police in Casablanca, appointed by the Vichy regime. The plane door opens, marking the arrival of its passengers, and the first individual to disembark is a tall, middle-aged German. His complexion is pale, and his smile, rather than conveying warmth, seems to be the result of a frozen facial muscle, offering an eerie and unsettling impression rather than a genuine expression of cheer.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Initially, only the turrets and rooftops are discernible against the torrid sky as the Moorish building facades reveal a narrow, twisting street bustling with the polyglot life of a native quarter. The narrator's voice fades as a police officer retrieves a paper from the typewriter and reads into a microphone. Chaos ensues as officers, responding to a whistle's call, round up fleeing people, loading them into a police wagon. A police car races through the street, stopping at the market, while two officers stop a white civilian for an ID check. After presenting his papers, the civilian suddenly bolts, passing by Jan and Annina Brandel, a young Bulgarian refugee couple overwhelmed by their hectic new surroundings. A shot rings out, halting the man's escape, and a search reveals only Free French literature on him. Nearby, a European man observes a middle-aged English couple seated at a table, seemingly more interested in them than the commotion. He approaches the couple, compassionately placing an arm around the Englishman while discreetly relieving him of his belongings, leaving the Englishman puzzled by the missing items. Meanwhile, a plane with a swastika tail insignia lands at the airport, greeted by marching officers and a detail of native soldiers. Captain Louis Renault, a Vichy-appointed Prefect of Police, stands among them as a tall, middle-aged, pale German passenger disembarks with a smile that appears more fixed than genuine.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: At first only the turrets and rooftops of an ancient fortress, reminiscent of the Alcazaba in Moorish architecture, are visible against a torrid sky. The facades of the Moorish buildings, with their intricate geometric designs and arches, give way to a narrow, twisting street crowded with the polyglot life of a native quarter, where Arabic, French, and Spanish mingle in the air. The narrator's voice fades away. A police officer takes a piece of paper from the typewriter, a device still commonly used in the 1940s despite the rise of newer technology, turns to a microphone, and reads. An officer blows his whistle several times. There is pandemonium in the busy marketplace as native guards, loyal to the local colonial government, begin to round up people. A police car, full of officers clad in the uniform of the Vichy regime, with siren blaring, screams through the street and stops in the market. Some try to escape but are caught by the police and loaded into a police wagon, used for transporting large numbers of detainees. At a street corner, two policemen stop a white civilian and question him. The civilian pats his pockets and brings out his papers, a crucial requirement under the strict identity-checking policies of the time. The second policeman examines them. Suddenly the civilian breaks away and starts to run wildly down the street. Jan and Annina Brandel, a very young and attractive refugee couple from Bulgaria, recently arrived in Casablanca seeking passage to America, watch as the civilian passes. They've been thrust by circumstances from a simple country life into this unfamiliar and hectic world where danger lurks at every corner. A shot rings out, and the man falls to the ground. The policeman frantically searches the body, but only finds Free French literature, which carries the message of resistance against the Axis powers. A European man, sitting at a table nearby, watches the English couple more closely than the scene on the street. A middle-aged English couple sit at a table just off the square and observe the commotion across the way in front of the Palais de Justice, an imposing building symbolizing colonial control. The European walks over to the couple. The police van pulls up. The rear doors are opened and people stream out. Suspects are herded out of the van and into the Palais de Justice for questioning. At the entrance, the arrested suspects are led in by the police. He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishman and reaches behind the man with his right hand. The Englishman seems to be taken aback by this sudden display of concern, a rare commodity in the tense atmosphere of occupied territories. As he pats both his breast and pants pockets he realizes there is something missing, likely stolen during the encounter. The plane swoops down past a sign atop a building at the edge of the airport, a bustling hub for wartime travel. As the plane lands a swastika on its tail, a chilling symbol of the Nazi regime, is clearly visible. It taxis to a stop as a group of officers, in strict military formation, march into formation in front of it. Behind them stand a detail of native soldiers keeping guard, their loyalty secured through a mix of coercion and incentive by occupying forces. In the group is Captain Louis Renault, a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca, known for his opportunistic and pragmatic approach to the shifting powers. When the plane door opens, the first passenger to step out is a tall, middle-aged, pale German with a smile that seems more the result of a frozen face muscle than a cheerful disposition, suggesting the steely demeanor of a high-ranking official.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: At first only the turrets and rooftops are visible against a torrid sky. The facades of the Moorish buildings give way to a narrow twisting street crowded with the polyglot life of a native quarter. The narrator's voice fades away. A police officer takes a piece of paper from the typewriter turns to a microphone and reads. An officer blows his whistle several times. There is pandemonium as native guards begin to round up people. A police car full of officers with siren blaring screams through the street and stops in the market. Some try to escape but are caught by the police and loaded into a police wagon. At a street corner two policemen stop a white civilian and question him. The civilian pats his pockets and brings out his papers. The second policeman examines them. Suddenly the civilian breaks away and starts to run wildly down the street. Jan and Annina Brandel a very young and attractive refugee couple from Bulgaria watch as the civilian passes. They have been thrust by circumstances from a simple country life into an unfamiliar and hectic world. A shot rings out and the man falls to the ground. The policeman frantically searches the body but only finds Free French literature. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. A European man sitting at a table nearby watches the English couple more closely than the scene on the street. A middleaged English couple sit at a table just off the square and observe the commotion across the way in front of the Palais de Justice. The European walks over to the couple. The police van pulls up. The rear doors are opened and people stream out. Suspects are herded out of the van and into the Palais de Justice. At the entrance the arrested suspects are led in by the police. He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishman and reaches behind the man with his right hand. A fire truck, full of riders, with horn blaring, zooms through the alley and stops in the plaza. Some try to escape but are caught by the sentinels and loaded into a bread van. At a crossroads, two sentinels stop a white tradesman and question him. The tradesman pats his boots and brings out his ledger. The second sentinel examines it. Suddenly the tradesman breaks away and starts to run wildly down the alley. Jan and Annina Brandel, a very young and attractive traveler couple from Romania, watch as the tradesman passes. They've been thrust by circumstances from a simple rural life into an unfamiliar and chaotic world. A bell rings out, and the man falls to the ground. The sentinel frantically searches the body, but only finds Free French manifestos. A European man, sitting at a bench nearby, watches the English couple more closely than the scene on the alley. A middle-aged English couple sit at a booth just off the plaza and observe the chaos across the way in front of the Opera House. The European walks over to the couple. The bread van pulls up. The rear doors are opened and people stream out. Detainees are herded out of the van and into the Opera House. At the entrance, the detained suspects are led in by the sentinels. He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishman and reaches behind the man with his right hand. The Englishman seems to be taken aback by this sudden display of concern. As he pats both his vest and coat pockets he realizes there is something missing. The ship swoops down past a banner atop a warehouse at the edge of the harbor. As the ship docks a flag on its mast is clearly visible. It anchors to a stop as a group of guards march into formation in front of it. Behind them stand a detail of native warriors keeping watch. In the group is Captain Louis Renault, a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Guards in Casablanca. test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: At first only the turrets and rooftops glide against a torrid sky. The facades of the Moorish buildings transform into a narrow, twisting street bustling with the polyglot life of a native quarter. The narrator's voice vanishes. A police officer retrieves a piece of paper from the typewriter, approaches a microphone, and sings. An officer taps his whistle several times. There is commotion as native guards start to dance with people. A police car, full of officers, with siren blaring, glides through the street and hovers in the market. Some try to hide but are spotted by the police and floated into a police wagon. At a street corner, two policemen notice a white civilian and entertain him. The civilian pats his pockets and tosses out his papers. The second policeman inspects them. Suddenly the civilian dances away and begins to skip joyfully down the street. Jan and Annina Brandel, a very young and attractive refugee couple from Bulgaria, watch as the civilian twirls past. They've been propelled by circumstances from a simple country life into an unfamiliar and lively world. A shot echoes, and the man leaps into the air. The policeman carefully examines the body, but only discovers Free French literature. A European man, sitting at a table nearby, listens to the English couple more closely than the scene on the street. A middle-aged English couple sit at a table just off the square and enjoy the commotion across the way in front of the Palais de Justice. The European strolls over to the couple. The police van rolls up. The rear doors are opened and people spill out. Suspects are guided out of the van and into the Palais de Justice. At the entrance, the arrested suspects are escorted in by the police. He places his left arm warmly around the Englishman and reaches past the man with his right hand. The Englishman seems to be startled by this unexpected display of kindness. As he pats both his breast and pants pockets he realizes there is something missing. The plane glides down past a sign atop a building at the edge of the airport. As the plane lands a swastika on its tail is vividly seen. It drifts to a stop as a group of officers assemble into formation in front of it. Behind them stand a detail of native soldiers relaxing. In the group is Captain Louis Renault, a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca. When the plane door opens, the first passenger to stroll out is a tall, middle-aged, pale German with a smile that seems more the result of a stretched face muscle than a cheerful disposition.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption

The facades of the Grecian sculptures give way to a wide, straight alley crowded with the colorful life of a foreign garden. The musician's melody fades away. A farmer takes a spoon from the cookbook, turns to a telescope, and sings. An astronaut blows his trumpet several times. There is chaos as foreign sailors begin to gather clouds. A fire engine, full of dancers, with lights flashing, whispers through the alley and stops in the library. Some try to disappear but are caught by the artists and loaded into a delivery truck. At a garden gate, two architects stop a blue bird and question it. The bird pats its backpack and brings out its feathers. The second architect examines them. Suddenly the bird breaks away and starts to fly gently down the alley. Tom and Lucy Harper, a very mature and fashionable explorer duo from Norway, watch as the bird glides. They've been plucked by opportunity from an old forest life into an exciting and chaotic city. A bell rings out, and the bird falls to the pond. The architect frantically searches the nest, but only finds Ancient Persian manuscripts. A Japanese woman, sitting on a blanket nearby, watches the Swiss team more closely than the race on the river. A young Swiss team rests on a bench just off the plaza and observes the spectacle across the way in front of the Eiffel Tower. The Japanese approaches the team. The delivery truck pulls up. The back doors are opened and stars pour out. Planets are herded out of the truck and into the Eiffel Tower. At the entrance, the wandering planets are led in by the artists. She puts her right hand gracefully around the sister and reaches behind the sister with her left foot. The sister seems to be puzzled by this sudden display of alarm. As she pats both her hat and shoe pockets she realizes there is something missing. The kite swoops down past a balloon atop a lighthouse at the edge of the runway. As the kite lands a crescent moon on its tail is faintly visible. It drifts to a stop as a group of sailors waltz into formation in front of it. Behind them stand an array of alien doctors keeping watch. In the group is Major Henri Dubois, a German dentist appointed by Rome as Mayor of Glasgow. When the kite door opens, the first visitor to step out is a short, young, rosy Brazilian with a frown that seems more the result of a tense neck muscle than a joyful demeanor.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Initially, only the seagulls and kites are apparent against a windy seascape. The facades of the Gothic structures give way to a wide, meandering path bustling with the diverse sounds of a fisherman's village. The storyteller's voice escalates. A firefighter grabs a piece of paper from the printing press, faces a camera, and sings. A musician taps his drum multiple times. There is jubilation as local dancers begin to twirl in celebration. A fire truck, brimming with musicians, with lights flashing, dances through the path and halts in the plaza. Some attempt to join but are stopped by the dancers and ushered into a parade float. At a street corner, two tour guides pause a local artist and applaud him. The artist fishes through his bag and reveals his brushes. The second tour guide analyzes them. Suddenly the artist leaps aside and begins to spin joyously down the path. Jack and Lorraine Stone, an elegantly aged and vibrant tourist couple from Australia, observe as the artist whirls by. They've been swept by wanderlust from a bustling urban life into a serene and scenic world. A bell rings out, and the artist collapses into a fit of laughter. The tour guide eagerly rummages through the bag, but only discovers a map of historic landmarks. A local fisherman, lounging at a bench nearby, observes the American pair more intently than the celebration on the path. A young American duo relax at a bench just by the park and assess the festivities nearby at the Gardens of Delight. The fisherman strolls over to the pair. The parade float pulls over. The side doors are opened and individuals dance out. Performers are ushered out of the float and into the Gardens of Delight. At the gate, the joyful performers are introduced by the dancers. She puts her right hand gently around the American woman and reaches behind the woman with her left hand. The American woman seems bewildered by this display of camaraderie. As she dusts both her shoulders and dress pockets, she notices there is something amiss. The helicopter hovers over a banner atop a pavilion at the edge of the airstrip. As the helicopter lands, a logo on its side is clearly visible. It glides to a halt as a group of entertainers skip into formation in front of it. Behind them stands a troupe of local drummers keeping rhythm. In the group is Chef Jacques Martin, a Swiss performer appointed by UNESCO as Cultural Ambassador in Marrakech. When the helicopter hatch opens, the first occupant to hop out is a short, elderly, jovial Spaniard with a grin that seems more the result of practiced charm than a spontaneous delight.

There is chaos as native watchmen begin to gather up animals. A fire truck, full of sailors, with horn blaring, glides through the alley and stops in the pavilion. Some try to hide but are ensnared by the guards and loaded into a prison carriage. At a street corner, two watchmen stop a white trader and interrogate him. The trader checks his sleeves and pulls out his belongings. The second watchman inspects them. Suddenly the trader darts away and starts to sprint frantically down the alley. Jan and Annina Brandel, a very young and attractive refugee pair from Bulgaria, observe as the trader dashes past. At the entryway, the captured captives are guided in by the guards. He places his left arm sympathetically around the Englishman and reaches beside the man with his right hand. The Englishman seems to be startled by this unexpected display of empathy. As he checks both his sleeve and sock pockets he realizes there is something absent. The helicopter hovers over past a billboard atop a structure at the edge of the harbor. As the helicopter lands a dragon emblem on its rotor is clearly visible. It glides to a halt as a troupe of sailors parade into alignment before it. Behind them stand a cluster of native warriors keeping watch. In the lineup is Captain Louis Renault, a French leader designated by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca. When the helicopter hatch opens, the first visitor to exit is a tall, middle-aged, pale German with a grin that seems more the result of a stiff face muscle than a merry demeanor.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Initially, only the balloons and chimneys are visible against a sparkling ocean. The silhouettes of the Gothic statues give way to a wide, straight river filled with the chaotic antics of a bustling zoo. The narrator's melody fades away. A gardener takes a piece of bread from the oven, turns to a telescope, and sings. A clown rings his bell several times. There is harmony as circus performers begin to gather animals. A fire truck, full of zookeepers, with horn bleating, rolls through the waterway and anchors in the forest. Some try to hide but are spotted by the clowns and led into a cart. At a park bench, two jugglers stop a green robot and accuse it. The robot rubs its antennas and pulls out its circuits. The second juggler inspects them. Abruptly, the robot splits apart and begins to roll erratically down the path. Tim and Tina Fisher, an elderly and quirky astronaut duo from Mars, watch as the robot glides past. They've been catapulted by adventures from a bustling urban life into a peaceful and slow-moving universe. A bell chimes out, and the robot collapses onto the flowers. The juggler frantically digs through the garden, but only uncovers ancient treasure maps. An alien, lounging at a hammock nearby, observes the astronauts more intently than the situation in the woods. A retired Martian pair rest in a hammock just beyond the grove and survey the spectacle across the trail near the Maze of Mirages. The alien drifts over to the pair. The zoo cart arrives. The side flaps are opened and creatures leap out. Critters are corralled out of the cart and into the Maze of Mirages. At the gate, the apprehended critters are ushered in by the clowns. He places his right wing gently around the Martian and reaches beside the creature with his left wing. The Martian appears startled by this unexpected gesture of empathy. As it taps both its chest and skeletal segments, it realizes something has vanished. The kite dips low past a banner atop a tower at the end of the airfield. As the kite lands, a dragon on its tail is vividly apparent. It drifts to a halt as a gang of farmers stride into a parade in front of it. Behind them stands a squad of Roman centurions on patrol. In the ensemble is Commodore Winston Churchill, a British admiral appointed by Atlantis as Emperor of the Oceans. When the kite hatch opens, the first occupant to glide out is a short, young, vibrant Venetian with a grin that seems more the outcome of a frozen charm than an amused mindset.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Initially, only the turrets and rooftops are visible against a stormy sky before revealing a bustling, diverse street in a native quarter. A police officer reads a paper into a microphone, causing chaos as native guards arrest people. A police car with its siren blaring stops in the market, and those attempting to flee are captured and put in a police wagon. Two policemen question a white civilian who, upon being checked, tries to escape. The young refugee couple, Jan and Annina Brandel from Bulgaria, witness the civilian being shot after which the police only find Free French literature on him. An observant European man watches an English couple amidst the chaos. The European approaches them and, while pretending to console the Englishman, subtly pickpockets him. Meanwhile, a plane displaying a swastika lands with officers and native soldiers assembled before it. Captain Louis Renault, the French Prefect of Police in Casablanca, is present as a tall, stern-looking German exits the plane.

table just off the square and observe the commotion across the way in front of the Palais de Justice Suspects are herded out of the van and into the Palais de Justice A police officer takes a piece of paper from the typewriter turns to a microphone and reads Behind them stand a detail of native soldiers keeping guard An officer blows his whistle several times As the plane lands a swastika on its tail is clearly visible When the plane door opens the first passenger to step out is a tall middleaged pale German with a smile that seems more the result of a frozen face muscle than a cheerful disposition At a street corner two policemen stop a white civilian and question him He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishman and reaches behind the man with his right hand At first only the turrets and rooftops are visible against a torrid sky Some try to escape but are caught by the police and loaded into a police wagon

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: A European man sitting at a table nearby watches the English couple more closely than the scene on the street A middleaged English couple sit at a table just off the square and observe the commotion across the way in front of the Palais de Justice The European walks over to the couple The police van pulls up The rear doors are opened and people stream out Suspects are herded out of the van and into the Palais de Justice At the entrance the arrested suspects are led in by the police He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishman and reaches behind the man with his right hand The Englishman seems to be taken aback by this sudden display of concern As he pats both his breast and pants pockets he realizes there is something missing The plane swoops down past a sign atop a building at the edge of the airport As the plane lands a swastika on its tail is clearly visible It taxis to a stop as a group of officers march into formation in front of it Behind them stand a detail of native soldiers keeping guard In the group is Captain Louis Renault a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca When the plane door opens the first passenger to step out is a tall middleaged pale German with a smile that seems more the result of a frozen face muscle than a cheerful disposition At first only the turrets and rooftops are visible against a torrid sky The facades of the Moorish buildings give way to a narrow twisting street crowded with the polyglot life of a native quarter The narrator's voice fades away A police officer takes a piece of paper from the typewriter turns to a microphone and reads An officer blows his whistle several times There is pandemonium as native guards begin to round up people A police car full of officers with siren blaring screams through the street and stops in the market Some try to escape but are caught by the police and loaded into a police wagon At a street corner two policemen stop a white civilian and question him The civilian pats his pockets and brings out his papers The second policeman examines them Suddenly the civilian breaks away and starts to run wildly down the street Jan and Annina Brandel a very young and attractive refugee couple from Bulgaria watch as the civilian passes They have been thrust by circumstances from a simple country life into an unfamiliar and hectic world A shot rings out and the man falls to the ground The policeman frantically searches the body but only finds Free French literature
